info.name: Duo Auth API [Child]
info.description:
This collection is designed to interact with the [Duo Auth API](https://duo.com/docs/authapi). The Duo Auth API is a low-level, RESTful API for adding strong two-factor authentication to your website or application, and can be used to perform a variety of connectivity and authentication tests.

#### ðŸš€ Getting started with this collection

**Step 1:** In the **Duo Auth API \[Child\]** collection, go to the variables tab and enter the desired child account's name in the `child_account_name` variable field. This name must match exactly as it appears in the Duo Admin Panel. To confirm the correct account name, you can use the 'Retrieve Accounts' request in the **Duo Accounts API** collection, which provides a list of child accounts and their names.

**Step2 :** After populating `child_account_name`, navigate to the **Setup Child Account** folder and execute the 'Deploy Auth API' request. This request creates an Admin API integration on the target acount, and populates the request credentials automatically for use.

**Step 3**: Be sure to configure any necessary or optional parameters for any particular request as specified in the Duo Admin API documentation. After setting up the environment variables and configuring parameters as needed, you're ready to utilize any request within the Duo Auth API \[Child\] collection.

#### ðŸ’¡ Collection Note

The collection performs multiple functions.

1. Duo Auth API: This request automates the deployment of the Auth API through a series of steps. Initially, it runs "Retrieve Accounts" to retrieve the list of child accounts and identifies the specific account ID by referencing the `child_account_name` variable. Subsequently, it creates the Auth API on the identified child account via "Create Integration" and obtains the secret key required for authentication via "Retrieve Secret Key." The script stores these values as both collection variables and in the `child_admin_api_matrix` for future use. In subsequent requests, it checks for existing entries in the matrix to determine if the Auth API \[Child\] already exists and updates the collection variables accordingly.
2. Clear Auth API Variables: This request serves to clear the values of the collection variables related to the Admin API. It resets the `child_account_name`, `child_account_account_id`, `child_auth_api_ikey`, `child_auth_api_skey`, and `child_auth_api_host` variables to empty values. It's important to clear the variables to ensure reqeust are run on the correct account.
    

#### ðŸ” Variable Reference

Below is a list of variables defined within this collection. Some variables are dynamically generated during API interactions, while others need to be manually configured.

| Variable Name | Description | Scope |
| --- | --- | --- |
| child_auth_api_ikey | Your Accounts API Integration Key. This needs to be manually set in the global variables. | Global |
| child_auth_api_skey | Your Accounts API Secret Key. This needs to be manually set in the global variables. | Global |
| child_auth_api_host | Your Accounts API Hostname. This needs to be manually set in the global variables. | Global |

exec: // Checks for an existing entry in child_auth_api_matrix
// Update collection variables with the details from the existing entry
console.log(`Auth API [Child] already exists on ${childAccountName} and is available for use.`);
// Return false if no existing entry was found
// If found, updates collection variables with the associated request credentials
var AUTH_TYPE = 'HMAC-SHA1'; // Define the authentication type
// Check if the API hostname is defined. If not, throw an error.
throw new Error("API_HOSTNAME is not defined");
//Adds a ? at the end of the URL even if there aren't any parameters, makes it easier to find the end of the api_call
// Get the index of the start of the query parameters in the URL
// Calculate the length of the hostname
// Extract the API endpoint from the requestUrl, by removing the hostname and the query parameters
var api_call = requestUrl.slice(hostname_length, paramsStart);  //remove hostname and params to get the api_call
// Clean up api_call by removing any unwanted characters
//Create unsorted array of parameters from either URL or Body
//Assuming POST parameters are in the Body, GET paramters are in URL
//(technically it looks like POST can be in the URL as well)
// Depending on the HTTP method and the existence of a request body,
// extract the query parameters from the URL or the body into params_array
if (params_array[0] !== ""){ //check if there are any Params to encode and create the string from
var encoded_params_array = params_array.map(urlEncodeParams);  //create URL-encoded array of key=value pairs from the sorted array
encoded_params = encoded_params_array.join("&");  //create string of parameters joined by &
// Get the current timestamp in the RFC 2822 format and store it in a collection variable for later use
var timestamp = moment().format("ddd, DD MMM YYYY HH:mm:ss ZZ");
// Construct the canonical string that is to be signed, by concatenating several request elements with newlines
// Compute the HMAC-SHA1 signature of the canonical string, using SKEY as the HMAC key
//Use HTTP Basic Authentication for the request, using your integration key as the username and the HMAC-SHA1 signature as the password.
var hostname_length = apiHostname.length + 8; // Length of 'https://' is 8
var timestamp = moment().format("ddd, DD MMM YYYY HH:mm:ss ZZ");

var requestData = timestamp + "
" + httpMethod + "
" + apiHostname + "
" + api_call + "
" + encoded_params + "
" + CryptoJS.SHA512(jsonDataString) + "
" + CryptoJS.SHA512("");
// Logic to set child_account_account_id and child_auth_api_host
//     // Extract relevant data from responseJson and set collection variables
// Extract relevant data from responseJson and set collection variables
// Check if childAccountName is not null and not empty
// Case when childAccountName is provided but no matching account is found
console.log(`No matching account found for ${childAccountName}. Please update the child_account_name collection variable with a correct account name.`);
// Case when childAccountName is null or empty
console.log("No account name found. Please update the child_account_name collection variable with the desired account name.");
console.log("Account ID is not set. Stopping execution.");
// Pre-check for existing integration in child_auth_api_matrix
var existingEntry = currentMatrix.find(entry => entry.accountName === childAccountName && entry.accountId === accountId);
console.log(`Duo Auth API [Child] already exists for ${childAccountName} and is available for use.`);
// Optionally, you can call retrieveSecretKey or any other function here if needed.
// Update matrix and proceed to retrieve the secret key
console.error(`Request 2 failed. HTTP status code: ${res.code}; Response:`, responseData);
// Retrieve childAccountName within this function to ensure it's defined
console.log("Account ID is not provided. Stopping execution.");
console.log("Child Account Name is not provided. Stopping execution.");
console.error('Network error on the second request:', err);
console.log(`Auth API [Child] created successfully on ${childAccountName} and is available for use.`);
console.error(`Second request failed. Response code: ${res.code}; Response:`, responseData);
function updateMatrix(accountId, childAccountName, integrationKey, secretKey, apiHostname) {
// Make sure getAccounts function is defined somewhere above this snippet
// Clear the values of the collection variables
// Retrieve the account name from the collection variable
// Log a message to confirm the action, specifically formatted as requested
console.log(`Cleared Auth API collection variables for.`);
// Log a message in the console

request.description:
TheÂ `/ping`Â endpoint acts as a "liveness check" that can be called to verify that Duo is up before trying to call other Auth API endpoints. Unlike the other endpoints, this one doesÂ **not**Â have to be signed with theÂ [Authorization header](https://duo.com/docs/authapi#authentication).

This endpoint is also suitable for use with Duo'sÂ [v2 Web SDK](https://duo.com/docs/duoweb-v2)Â to verify that Duo's service is responding before initializing frame authentication.

exec: // Log a message in the console
console.log("Auth API integration and secret keys are valid. The signature is being generated properly.");
console.log("There seems to be an issue. Please check the API integration and secret keys.");

request.description:
TheÂ `/check`Â endpoint can be called to verify that the Auth API integration and secret keys are valid, and that the signature is being generated properly.

This endpoint is also suitable for use with Duo'sÂ [v2 Web SDK](https://duo.com/docs/duoweb-v2)Â to verify integration information before initializing frame authentication.

exec: // Log a message in the console
console.log("Success, the response body is Content-Type image/png, containing the logo.");
// Log a message in the console
console.log("Success, created enrollment code for new user.");
console.log("Invalid or missing parameters, or a user with username already exists.");

query.description: Optional: Username for the created user. If not given, a random username will be assigned and returned.
Optional: Seconds for which the activation code will remain valid. Default: 86400 (one day).

request.description: TheÂ `/enroll`Â endpoint provides a programmatic way to enroll new users with Duo two-factor authentication. It creates the user in Duo and returns a code (as a QR code) that Duo Mobile can scan with its built-in camera. Scanning the QR code adds the user's account to the app so that they receive and respond to Duo Push login requests.

exec: // Log a message in the console
console.log("Invalid or missing parameters, verify user_id and activation_code parameters.");

query.description: Required: Activation code, as returned from /enroll.

request.description: Check whether a user has completed enrollment.

exec: // Log a message in the console
console.log("Successfully verified users log in status and available authentication factors.");
console.log("Invalid or missing parameters, or the specified username is not in a state that allows preauth to complete successfully.");

query.description: Required: if username is not specified: Permanent, unique identifier for the user as generated by Duo upon user creation (e.g. DUYHV6TJBC3O4RITS1WC).

Required: if user_id is not specified: Unique identifier for the user that is commonly specified by your application during user creation (e.g. user@domain.com). This value may also represent a username alias assigned to a user
Optional: The IP address of the user to be authenticated, in dotted quad format. This will cause an "allow" response to be sent if appropriate for requests from a trusted network.
Optional: The host name of the device accessing the application.

Optional: If the trusted_device_token is present and the Auth API application has an effective policy that enables Remembered Devices for each browser-based application, return an "allow" response for the lifetime of the token as set by the Duo administrator in the policy.

request.description: TheÂ `/preauth`Â endpoint determines whether a user is authorized to log in, and (if so) returns the user's available authentication factors.

exec: // Log a message in the console
console.log("Successfully verified users log in status and available authentication factors.");
console.log("Invalid or missing parameters, or the specified username is not in a state that allows preauth to complete successfully.");

query.description: Required: if username is not specified: Permanent, unique identifier for the user as generated by Duo upon user creation (e.g. DUYHV6TJBC3O4RITS1WC).

Required: if user_id is not specified: Unique identifier for the user that is commonly specified by your application during user creation (e.g. user@domain.com). This value may also represent a username alias assigned to a user

Required: Factor to use for authentication. Currently, the following choices are supported:
auto: Use recommended out-of-band factor (push or phone).
push: Authenticate with Duo Push.
passcode: Authenticate with a passcode (Duo Mobile, SMS, hardware token, bypass code).
sms: Send SMS passcodes (note: does not authenticate, requires re-prompt).
phone: Authenticate with phone callback.

Required: ID of the device. This device must have the "push" capability.

You may also specify "auto" to use the first of the user's devices with the "push" capability.
Optional: The IP address of the user to be authenticated, in dotted quad format. This will cause an "allow" response to be sent if appropriate for requests from a trusted network.
Optional: The host name of the device accessing the application.

Optional: If the trusted_device_token is present and the Auth API application has an effective policy that enables Remembered Devices for each browser-based application, return an "allow" response for the lifetime of the token as set by the Duo administrator in the policy.

request.description: TheÂ `/preauth`Â endpoint determines whether a user is authorized to log in, and (if so) returns the user's available authentication factors.

exec: // Log a message in the console
console.log("Invalid or missing parameters, verify the txid param is correct.");

query.description: Required: The transaction ID of the authentication attempt, as returned by the /auth endpoint.

request.description: TheÂ `/auth_status`Â endpoint "long-polls" for the next status update from the authentication process for a given transaction. That is to say, if no status update is available at the time the request is sent, it will wait until there is an update before returning a response.

exec: // Require 'url' module to use its methods for handling and transforming URLs.
// Get the hostname for the accounts API from Postman collection variables.
// Declare a variable to hold Duo Authentication Version
function getAuthHeader(httpMethod, hostname, path, q_str, requestBody, duo_auth_ver) {
var IKEY = pm.collectionVariables.get("child_auth_api_ikey"); //Auth or Admin API IKEY
var SKEY = pm.collectionVariables.get("child_auth_api_skey"); //Auth or Admin API SKEY
var API_HOSTNAME = pm.collectionVariables.get("child_auth_api_host"); //Auth or Admin API Hostname
//The current time, formatted as RFC 2822. This must be the same string as the "Date" header (or X-Duo-Date header).
var timestamp = moment().format("ddd, DD MMM YYYY HH:mm:ss ZZ");
//Create unsorted array of parameters from either URL or Body
//Assuming POST parameters are in the Body, GET paramters are in URL
//(technically it looks like POST can be in the URL as well)
if (params_array[0] !== ""){            //check if there are any Params to encode and create the string from
var encoded_params_array = params_array.map(urlEncodeParams);   //create URL-encoded array of key=value pairs from the sorted array
encoded_params = encoded_params_array.join("&");                //create string of parameters joined by &
//compute the HMAC-SHA1 of this canonical representation, using your Duo application's secret key as the HMAC key
var encoded_params_array = params_array.map(urlEncodeParams);   //create URL-encoded array of key=value pairs from the sorted array
var encoded_params_array = params_array.map(urlEncodeParams);   //create URL-encoded array of key=value pairs from the sorted array
//compute the HMAC-SHA1 of this canonical representation, using your Duo application's secret key as the HMAC key
//Use HTTP Basic Authentication for the request, using your integration key as the username and the HMAC-SHA1 signature as the password.
// Check if the request url includes '/v1/' or '/v2/' and set the Duo Authentication Version accordingly
// Check if the request URL includes '{{accountId}}'
// Check if the request URL includes '{{ChildAccount}}'
// Check if the request URL includes '{{ChildAccount}}'
// Check if the request URL includes '{{temp_policy_key}}'
// Replace '{{ChildAccount}}' in req_url with the value of ChildAccount
// Check if the request URL includes '{{temp_policy_key_b}}'
// Replace '{{ChildAccount}}' in req_url with the value of ChildAccount
// Check if the request URL includes '{{username}}'
// Check if the request URL includes '{{email}}'
// Check if the request URL includes '{{email}}'
// Check if the request URL includes '{{group_idl}}'
// Parse the query string from the request url
// Check if the query string is null. If it is, set it to an empty string
// Parse the path from the request url, remove the leading '/', then rejoin the path
// Get the 'temp_integration_key' value from Postman collection variables
// Replace '{{temp_integration_key}}' in the path with the actual integration key
// Get the 'temp_integration_key_b' value from Postman collection variables
// Replace '{{temp_integration_key_b}}' in the path with the actual integration key
// Get the 'user_id' value from Postman collection variables
// Replace '{{user_id}}' in the path with the actual user id.
// Get the 'global_policy_key' value from Postman collection variables
// Replace '{{user_id}}' in the path with the actual user id.
pm.globals.set("hmacAuthHeader", getAuthHeader(request.method, hostname, path, q_str, request.data, duo_auth_ver));
